results.title: Writing, plain and fancy
results.creator_credit: Mallory Pearce, Severo Perez and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Surveys the evolution of written communication. Beginning with the Romans and their invention of capital letters, the program continues through the reign of the great King Charlemagne who standardized the alphabet. The importance of legible writing for good communication is stressed. Narrated by John Houseman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mallory Pearce, Severo Perez and Walt Disney Productions

results.title: Destination: science
results.creator_credit: Fern Field, EPCOT Educational Media and Focal Video
results.brief_description: Combines animation and live action as Donald Duck is invited to tour the world of science beyond the laboratory. Flight, the electric light bulb and computers are used to illustrate the relevance of inquiry and discovery in our daily lives. Part of the series “Journey to tomorrow”.

results.title: The Challenge of survival: chemicals
results.creator_credit: Paul Gerber, Dick Young Productions and EPCOT Educational Media
results.brief_description: Shows how advances in agricultural research have increased our crop yields but have at the same time created a serious threat to our natural resources. Illustrates how our current use of chemicals has led to the poisoning of the environment and resistance developed amongst some pests. Examines alternative methods of pest management. Narrated by Michael Kane.

results.title: Waltzing Matilda: touring Australia
results.brief_description: A tourist promotion that intermingles aspects of Australian history and culture with holiday promotion. Narrated by Charles Tingwell with original music by Bruce Smeaton. The song “Walzing Matilda” played by the Bushwackers Band is used as a theme.

results.title: Rectangle & rectangles & rectangle
results.creator_credit: Rene Jodoin, Robert Forget and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is a didactic film in disguise. A progression of brilliant geometric shapes bombard the screen to the insistent beat of drums. The filmmaker programmed a computer to coordinate a highly complex operation involving an electronic beam of light, colour filters and a camera. This animation film, without words, is designed to expose the power of the cinematic medium, and to illustrate the abstract nature of time. Animation by Rene Jodoin with assistance in computer animation by Doris Kochanek and Daniel Langlois. Music score by Normand Roger, sound by Louis Hone.

results.title: Discover Sweden
results.creator_credit: Dag Bengtsson, D Tranword Communications, J and Journal Films
results.brief_description: Provides a general introduction to the social geography of Sweden. Presents visual and factual information on landscape, industries, transport and settlement, banking systems, politics, and education. Focuses on the country’s people describing the sports they enjoy, their religion and social customs. Useful for regional studies of Europe. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Modern Europe: Norway
results.brief_description: Describes the geography of Norway from its mountains 8000 feet above sea level, to its lowland regions and fjords. Norways major industries are tourism, fishing, shipbuilding, agriculture, forestry and iron smelting. Also shows Norways landmarks, buildings of interest and ancient rock carvings. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Beyond words: animal communication
results.creator_credit: Wolfgang Bayer, National Geographic Society and Wolfgang Bayer Productions
results.brief_description: Provides an overview of animals communicating for various reasons. Examples of calls and other communications amongst animals are then catalogued. Teachers guide included. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Volcanoes, earthquakes, and other earth movements
results.creator_credit: Reinald Werrenrath Jr and Goldberg-Werrenrath Productions
results.brief_description: Indicates that volcanoes and earthquakes are evidence of a natural process called plate tectonics. Shows how to chart part movements of these crustal plates and how to make predictions about their movements. The program also uses excellent location film such as the eruption of the Mt St Helens volcano in Norther America. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
